courseTitle: Principles of Risk Management and Insurance
courseDescription: Recommended elective for non-business as well as business majors. The primary focus of this introductory course is on evaluating life, health, retirement, property, liability and personnel exposures to loss and analyzing the methods for managing these risks. Risk management and insurance techniques for dealing with potential losses to individuals and organizations will be emphasized. Classwork and a group project will also cover emerging risks, such as cyber risk, and technologies disrupting the industry. Students receiving a B or better in this course can have it count as the CPCU 500 course of the Chartered Property-Casualty Underwriter (CPCU) professional designation.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of emerging risks and technologies
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presentation of risk analysis and management strategies
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification and evaluation of exposure to loss

courseDescription: Available for pass/fail grading only. May be repeated for credit up to a maximum of 6 credits. Approval for enrollment and allowable credits are determined by the risk management and insurance advisor and Career Development Services in accordance with the policy for granting credit for Cooperative Education programs.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective Communication with Career Development Services
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding and adhering to policy for granting credit
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Self-organization for meeting course credit requirements

courseDescription: A faculty supervised, professionally oriented project. Approval for enrollment and allowable credits is determined by the Risk Management advisor.  A transfer student must have completed one semester at Old Dominion University.

This course uses a broad-based financial planning approach in considering the nature and importance of individual life and health risks and uses of individual life and health insurance in treating these risks. The implications of various legal, tax, and accounting considerations on businesses and individuals are discussed. The course also provides an overview of the operational aspects of life insurers, including organization, underwriting, actuarial, reinsurance, marketing, investment, taxation, and accounting functions. Cases are employed.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing legal, tax, and accounting implications on businesses and individuals

courseDescription: This course considers the ability of group insurance and other private pooling mechanisms to alleviate the financial problems arising from death, disability, medical treatment and retirement. Primary emphasis on design, tax and administrative characteristics as they relate to employer-sponsored benefit programs. Cases are employed.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Financial problem-solving for death, disability, medical treatment, and retirement scenarios
Analyzing tax characteristics of benefit programs

courseDescription: The course provides a broad overview of the operational activities and current problems of property and liability insurance companies, including organization, regulation, pricing, underwriting, claims, reinsurance, marketing, investment, and accounting functions. Classwork and a group project will also cover emerging risks, such as cyber risk, and technologies disrupting the industry. Students receiving a B or better in this course can have it count as the CPCU 520 course of the Chartered Property-Casualty Underwriter (CPCU) professional designation.
Technical and Digital Skills: Investment and accounting functions in insurance
Understanding of emerging risks like cyber risk
Adaptation to technologies disrupting the insurance industry
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification and analysis of current problems in the insurance industry
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management and coordination in group projects
Leading discussions on emerging risks and industry disruptions

courseDescription: Recommended elective for non-business as well as business majors. This course focuses on the risk analysis and control phases of the risk management process in business and governmental organizations. Particular attention is paid to the recognition, measurement, and treatment of traditional and emerging risks, risk financing options other than commercial insurance, and decision making under conditions of uncertainty. Classwork and a group project will also cover emerging risks, such as cyber risk, and technologies disrupting the industry.
Technical and Digital Skills: Recognition of traditional and emerging risks
Understanding of cyber risks and technologies disrupting the industry
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Decision making under conditions of uncertainty

courseDescription: This course is designed as a capstone course for students majoring or minoring in risk management and insurance. The class will be introduced to all aspects of enterprise risk management (ERM), which is the emerging paradigm in risk management. Classwork and a group project will also cover emerging risks, such as cyber risk, and technologies disrupting the industry.
Technical and Digital Skills: Familiarity with technologies disrupting the industry

courseDescription: For advanced students in risk management and insurance.
